line: The dos and
label: heading

line: Design Professional
label: heading

line: don’ts of NDAs
label: heading

line: Signing an owner’s nondisclosure agreement may be an accepted part of doing business,
label: heading

line: but some of the terms owners seek to impose on designers are just plain unacceptable.
label: heading

line: While many people might associate nondisclosure agreements,
label: paragraph

line: or NDAs, with Silicon Valley startups or Hollywood studios that
label: paragraph

line: don’t want their next big ideas made public, there are also many
label: paragraph

line: reasons why project owners request that design professionals sign
label: paragraph

line: NDAs: to keep proprietary information out of competitors’ hands;
label: paragraph

line: to keep deliberations over various means, methods or solutions
label: paragraph

line: secret; or to prevent others from learning about an entity’s overall
label: paragraph

line: strategy until absolutely necessary.
label: paragraph

line: Typically, an owner will request that a designer sign an NDA before
label: paragraph

line: negotiating or finalizing a contract in an attempt to keep the
label: paragraph

line: project details—or even its existence—secret, whether or not the
label: paragraph

line: designer ends up participating in the project.
label: paragraph

line: AXA XL’s Design Professional team cautions design professionals
label: paragraph

line: to regard NDAs as they do contracts, i.e., read them carefully
label: paragraph

line: before signing. We’ve seen cases in which the A/E has signed an
label: paragraph

line: NDA without fully understanding its implications.
label: paragraph

line: “Some architects or engineers willingly sign NDAs without
label: paragraph

line: examining the language and comprehending the penalties they
label: paragraph

line: are accepting, including agreeing to penalties without proof of a
label: paragraph

line: breach,” says Nancy Rigassio, Executive Claims Counsel for AXA
label: paragraph

line: XL’s Design Professional team. “My guess is that when owners
label: paragraph

line: propose confidentiality agreements while the parties work out the
label: paragraph

line: professional services agreement, many design professionals see
label: paragraph

line: the confidentiality agreement as a preliminary—and temporary—
label: paragraph

line: step in the process.”
label: paragraph

line: While most designers might not intentionally divulge confidential
label: paragraph

line: information, there are plenty of situations in which someone
label: paragraph

line: might unintentionally let the cat out of the bag. For example,
label: paragraph

line: let’s say you were invited to discuss the building of a new big-box
label: paragraph

line: store in a town that has traditionally patronized local businesses.
label: paragraph

line: After your meeting, someone overhears you and your colleagues
label: paragraph

line: discussing the project in a nearby restaurant. Even worse, one
label: paragraph

line: of your junior staff members, after hearing about this potential
label: paragraph

line: feather in your firm’s cap, decides to post the news on social
label: paragraph

line: media. Before you know it, local merchants have formed an
label: paragraph

line: organization to protest the project.
label: paragraph

line: Another possible scenario is that your firm might suffer a data
label: paragraph

line: breach. In such a case, the owner’s confidential material could
label: paragraph

line: be stolen and, once the theft was discovered, you would have to
label: paragraph

line: notify the owner of the breach as required by law. Since the owner
label: paragraph

line: would likely accuse you of violating the NDA, you’d find yourself
label: paragraph

line: in the most difficult position of having to prove that the owner’s
label: paragraph

line: confidential material was not stolen.
label: paragraph

line: What’s “confidential”?
label: heading

line: The problem with many, if not most, of these owner-written NDAs
label: paragraph

line: is that they’re so broad in scope that a designer of any tenure
label: paragraph

line: would have a tough time not violating the terms, no matter how
label: paragraph

line: careful the designer, because everything about the project could
label: paragraph

line: be deemed confidential.
label: paragraph

line: Rather than precisely limit the information the owner wants to
label: paragraph

line: be kept confidential, these troublesome NDAs cast as wide a net
label: paragraph

line: as possible. Consider, for example, the following passage from an
label: paragraph

line: NDA a designer was asked to sign:
label: paragraph

line: …Confidential Information is defined as all data and
label: paragraph

line: information relating to the Owner’s activities, operations,
label: paragraph

line: practices, or customers that the Consultant learns during its
label: paragraph

line: interactions with the Owner…shall include but is not limited to
label: paragraph

line: the following…financial plans and data; product development;
label: paragraph

line: trade secrets; business plans; operational methods; marketing
label: paragraph

line: plans or strategies; pricing information; customer files; material
label: paragraph

line: and product specifications; personnel and compensation
label: paragraph

line: policies…and other similar information.
label: paragraph

line: At least this NDA sets forth a definition of what is to be deemed
label: paragraph

line: confidential—most NDAs don’t. But note the use of “other
label: paragraph

line: similar information.” That only adds to this clause’s already-too-
label: paragraph

line: expansive definition of “confidential information.”
label: paragraph

line: “Owners deliberately want a very broad definition to include
label: paragraph

line: information not even contemplated at the early phase of the
label: paragraph

line: project,” Rigassio says. “But defining confidential information as
label: paragraph

line: broadly as possible places an unfair burden on the designer.”
label: paragraph

line: It’s up to you to revise the agreement to define confidential
label: paragraph

line: information as that information the owner specifically designates
label: paragraph

line: to you as confidential.
label: paragraph

line: Public responsibility
label: heading

line: As a licensed design professional, you have an ethical obligation
label: paragraph

line: to protect public health and safety, a duty which overrides
label: paragraph

line: any obligation to the owner. However, if you were to discover
label: paragraph

line: something, or if the owner were to ask you to do something,
label: paragraph

line: that you believed would be contrary to the ethical code, and you
label: paragraph

line: decided to report it, you could find yourself in violation of the
label: paragraph

line: NDA.
label: paragraph

line: Potential costs
label: heading

line: In this next clause, a different owner’s proposed NDA describes
label: paragraph

line: the consequences of disclosing what the owner subjectively
label: paragraph

line: considers confidential information:
label: paragraph

line: In the event of any breach of this Agreement by Consultant,
label: paragraph

line: Consultant shall pay the Company liquidated damages equal
label: paragraph

line: to $25,000 for each such breach. The Parties hereby agree
label: paragraph

line: that in the event of such a breach, actual damages would be
label: paragraph

line: impractical or impossible to ascertain, such liquidated damages

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: The attempt to impose an arbitrary amount of damages makes an
label: paragraph

line: assumption that the disclosure of information caused the owner
label: paragraph

line: irreparable harm, and improperly shifts the burden of proof from
label: paragraph

line: the owner to the designer. This shift will require the designer
label: paragraph

line: to carry the burden of, in effect, proving a negative—that the
label: paragraph

line: disclosure did not involve information that was confidential, and
label: paragraph

line: that the disclosure did not cause harm to the owner.
label: paragraph

line: According to Rigassio, “Owners don’t want the burden of having
label: paragraph

line: to prove the elements of causation or damages. They just want
label: paragraph

line: the A/E to concede, ‘Yes, our actions have caused you irreparable
label: paragraph

line: harm and the damages would be so severe they’re impossible to
label: paragraph

line: determine, so we will agree to your imposition of damages in the
label: paragraph

line: amount of $X per breach.’”
label: paragraph

line: Under these terms, if your intended lead designer on the
label: paragraph

line: proposed project disclosed confidential information on
label: paragraph

line: Monday and your intended project manager disclosed different
label: paragraph

line: confidential information on Tuesday, you’d already owe $50,000
label: paragraph

line: (a sum that may not be covered by your professional liability
label: paragraph

line: insurance policy). And you may not even win the project!
label: paragraph

line: Managing your risk
label: heading

line: One thing to keep in mind is that NDAs, like contracts and so many
label: paragraph

line: other aspects of a designer’s services, are negotiable. “There’s
label: paragraph

line: nothing wrong with signing an NDA,” Rigassio says, “What can get
label: paragraph

line: you into trouble is signing one that fails to require the owner to
label: paragraph

line: specifically identify what information is confidential, and allows
label: paragraph

line: the owner to take a shortcut around proving the elements of
label: paragraph

line: causation and damages.” To that end, AXA XL offers the following
label: paragraph

line: loss prevention advice:
label: paragraph

line:  Read the non-disclosure agreement word-for-word. Just
label: paragraph

line: because it looks like a standard agreement, don’t be fooled
label: paragraph

line: into complacency. That “fine print” you may be tempted to
label: paragraph

line: ignore (particularly if you’re asked to sign the agreement at the
label: paragraph

line: beginning of a meeting, while everyone’s waiting) is exactly
label: paragraph

line: where the owner may have tucked the right to obtain injunctive
label: paragraph

line: relief without having to carry the burden of proof, or the
label: paragraph

line: liquidated damages remedy.
label: paragraph

line: When reviewing, keep an eye out for language such as “any and
label: paragraph

line: all data and information,” “other similar information,” or other
label: paragraph

line: language that is so broad that it covers a disclosure of practically
label: paragraph

line: anything.
label: paragraph

line:  Include language that obligates the owner to specifically
label: paragraph

line: designate the information deemed confidential. The owner
label: paragraph

line: should be able to tell you which information you can’t disclose
label: paragraph

line: and which you can.
label: paragraph

line:  Make sure the agreement places the burden on the owner to
label: paragraph

line: prove the elements of a cause of action, including the existence
label: paragraph

line: of irreparable harm to the owner and the monetary value. Some
label: paragraph

line: NDAs will define confidential information as “information not
label: paragraph

line: generally known by the public.” That means if you disclose
label: paragraph

line: something you believe is public information and the owner
label: paragraph

line: cries foul, then the burden will be on you to prove that it isn’t
label: paragraph

line: confidential, which can be difficult and time-consuming.
label: paragraph

line:  Make sure you have NDAs with your subconsultants. You
label: paragraph

line: don’t want to get into a situation in which it’s alleged that you
label: paragraph

line: inappropriately shared confidential information with an HVAC
label: paragraph

line: engineer that never executed an NDA with you.
label: paragraph

line:  To avoid violating the NDA by reporting a public health and
label: paragraph

line: safety-endangering request from the owner, include a public
label: paragraph

line: responsibility provision in the NDA. In effect, the clause should
label: paragraph

line: read that the owner will not ask you to take any action that
label: paragraph

line: conflicts with your professional code of ethics and that, should
label: paragraph

line: the owner do so, it is agreed that if you report the request to
label: paragraph

line: the appropriate parties, the owner will not pursue legal action
label: paragraph

line: against you for violating the NDA.

label: paragraph

line: Nondisclosure agreements play an important role in the
label: paragraph

line: relationship between owners and design professionals. In some
label: paragraph

line: ways, they help protect not just the owner, but also the designer,
label: paragraph

line: by underlining the importance of keeping certain information
label: paragraph

line: confidential to promote the project objectives. The key is to
label: paragraph

line: become fully aware of what you’re signing and its implications
label: paragraph

line: and to negotiate fair terms that reflect what the law requires.
label: paragraph

line: Make sure the NDA places the burden
label: paragraph

line: on the owner to prove the elements
label: paragraph

line: of a cause of action.
